newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Castro to be invited to EU/Latam summit.
newsitem.headline: Castro to be invited to EU/Latam summit.

text.p: Cuban leader Fidel Castro will be invited to attend a first European Union/Latin America summit scheduled to take place in either Panama or Brazil in the next 18 months, EU officials said on Tuesday.

"I am glad to say that a summit will take place although we do not yet have a final date or venue," said one diplomat attending a meeting of EU and Latin America foreign ministers at this Dutch seaside town.

Asked if Castro -- increasingly being isolated by Western governments who have lost patience with his unwillingness to accept democratic reform in Cuba -- would be invited, the diplomat said: "At this stage, yes. We all want him to come."
Officials from Europe and Latin America were on Tuesday comparing calendars to see when a summit could take place.
The EU has ruled out any time during the current Dutch and forthcoming Luxembourg and British presidencies as the 15-nation bloc is likely to be too occupied by economic and monetary union matters.
Officials said the task of co-organising the summit is likely to fall to Portugal, which takes charge for six months in the second half of 1998.

Although the EU does not have political links with Latin America as a whole, the summit will be arranged by combining the San Jose and Rio groups -- the two organisations with which the Europeans do have links -- and any countries not in either.
Castro's invitation is likely to irritate the United States which has made no secret of its desire to see Havana isolated by the international community.
EU and Latin American nations, however, favour dialogue with Castro as a means of prising Cuba out of the communist shell it has occupied since 1959.
